TowerDefense

Class Projectile

  • java.lang.Object
    • Engine.GameObject
      • TowerDefense.GameObjectPlus
        • TowerDefense.Projectile

  • public class Projectile
extends GameObjectPlus
    A projectile is an object that is thrown by a Character. They impact the target's health and badFeels. NOTE: May be a bit out of data, as the Hug The Line game hasn't used these for a few months.
    Author:
    Branden Drake, Rachel Horton

      • Nested classes/interfaces inherited from class Engine.GameObject

      • Projectile

        public Projectile(float xLoc,
                  float yLoc,
                  float width,
                  float height,
                  Destructible target,
                  Character creator)
        Constructor
        Parameters:
        xLoc - X-coordinate of location.
        yLoc - Y-coordinate of location.
        width - Width in space.
        height - Height in space.
        target - The target of the projectile.
        creator - The Character throwing the projectile.

        When a new projectile is created, it will automatically be placed in the list specified here.
        Parameters:
        projectileList -

      • setSpeed

        public static boolean setSpeed(float speed)
        Set the speed value of all projectiles. We never figured out the units this speed is in. Speed must be at least zero.
        Parameters:
        speed -
        Returns:
        True if the speed was actually changed.

      • getSpeed

        public static float getSpeed()
        Returns:
        The default speed of projectiles.

        public void setHealthAdjust(float val)
        Sets the amount of health that should be lost by target when projectile hits it
        Parameters:

      • setSpeedUpMultiplier

        public void setSpeedUpDuration(float time)
        If this projectile hits a target, the target's speed will be adjusted for this amount of time.
        Parameters:

      • shouldBeDestroyed

        public boolean shouldBeDestroyed()
        Checks if the projectile should be destroyed. The lists that contain Projectiles are responsible for checking this and then removing them.
        Returns:
        True if the projectile has lived out its usefulness
